p: The effect of fish oils in disease prevention and management has been studied for more than 50 years. Fish oils, which are rich in fatty acids, show evidence of potential health benefits [ 1]. Large amounts of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) are found in the extracts of fish oils. Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) and eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), which are long-chain omega-3 fatty acids, are the predominant PUFAs derived from fish oils. The interest in fish oils arose from the reports on Eskimos’ high dietary intake of fish oils associated with a very low occurrence of inflammation-related diseases and ischemic heart disorders [ 2]. Besides vitamins and minerals, fish oils are the most frequently used nutritional supplements in older adults >65 years of age [ 3]. The PUFAs in fish oils have proved to be beneficial for treating rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, ulcerative colitis, asthma, Parkinson’s disease, osteoporosis, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular events, cancers, and depression [ 4]. PUFAs also demonstrate beneficial activity on the development of the nervous, immune, visual, and cutaneous systems in infants [ 5].
